item.title: Merge .csv files into a single .xlsx file with ssconvert
item.description:
In a previous note, I explained how to convert .xlsx into .csv with ssconvert. Today, I wanted to do the reverse operation, so I looked up on the Internet and found this answer on ubuntu forums: assuming you need to merge file1.csv and file2.csv into all.xlsx (in two separate sheets) then all you have to do is:

ssconvert --merge-to=all.xlsx file1.csv file2.csv

The short option for --merge-to= is -M (see man ssconvert), so what I did was:

item.title: .xlsx to .csv with ssconvert
item.description:
Even if I use Calc more often than Gnumeric (and actually I tried to spend as less time as possible on spreadsheet programs), the latter provides a tool I’m fond of, ssconvert:

ssconvert - a command line spreadsheet format converter

It offers a very efficient way to convert .xlsx into .csv, for instance:

1
2

mkdir csvFiles
ssconvert -S spreadsheet.xlsx csvFiles/%s.csv
